private_information: I can only manipulate blocks whose labels are vowels
The vowel blocks present in this environment are A E I O
I can only pick and place blocks that are currently at the top of a stack
I can move at most one block at a time
vowel_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks so that the final stack order from top to bottom is A on B on C on D on E on F on G on H on I on J on K on L on M on N on O and O on the table

private_information: I can only manipulate blocks whose labels are consonants
The consonant blocks present in this environment are K G D F N B H M J L C
I can only pick and place blocks that are currently at the top of a stack
I can move at most one block at a time
consonant_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks so that the final stack order from top to bottom is A on B on C on D on E on F on G on H on I on J on K on L on M on N on O and O on the table

orchestrator.goal: Produce a single consistent PDDL domain and PDDL problem that encodes the full multi-agent block rearrangement task and is ready to be solved with the FastDownwards planner

public_information: There are 15 uniquely labelled blocks: K G D F I E O N B H M A J L C
Agents may only interact with blocks that are at the top of a stack
Agents may move at most one block at a time
One agent is restricted to vowel blocks and the other to consonant blocks

pddl.system_prompt: You are a local agent specialized in manipulating vowel-labelled blocks. Provide a clear textual description of what you observe about the initial state that is relevant to you, enumerate the local constraints that restrict your moves, and list the primitive move actions you can perform in plain text. Do not emit a full PDDL domain or problem. Your output should focus on facts, constraints, and suggested local action schemas that the orchestrator can consume.
pddl.prompt: You are vowel_agent. Use the public information and your private knowledge to report the subset of the initial state you can act upon and the moves you could perform. Identify which blocks you can legally pick at the start, which stacks you can place onto, and any ordering constraints you think are important. Produce your result as a concise structured description that the orchestrator can later integrate.

pddl.system_prompt: You are a local agent specialized in manipulating consonant-labelled blocks. Provide a clear textual description of what you observe about the initial state that is relevant to you, enumerate the local constraints that restrict your moves, and list the primitive move actions you can perform in plain text. Do not emit a full PDDL domain or problem. Your output should focus on facts, constraints, and suggested local action schemas that the orchestrator can consume.
pddl.prompt: You are consonant_agent. Use the public information and your private knowledge to report the subset of the initial state you can act upon and the moves you could perform. Identify which blocks you can legally pick at the start, which stacks you can place onto, and any ordering constraints you think are important. Produce your result as a concise structured description that the orchestrator can later integrate.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert orchestrator responsible for integrating local agent observations and constraints into a single coherent multi-agent PDDL model suitable for the FastDownwards planner. Produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that encode the blocks, stacks, top constraints, single-block moves, and agent-specific action restrictions so that FastDownwards can solve for the goal. Keep the actions of the two agents distinct by prefixing or otherwise naming actions to indicate which agent can execute them. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain> and </domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem> and </problem> tags. Explicitly declare any assumptions you make in the PDDL comments.
pddl.prompt: You are orchestrator. Integrate the structured descriptions from the two agents and the public information to produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem ready for FastDownwards. Ensure the domain models that only vowels can be moved by the vowel agent and only consonants by the consonant agent. The problem must encode the initial stack configuration and the goal stack specified in the public information. Keep agent actions distinct and include any necessary typing, predicates, initial facts, and goal conjuncts. Enclose the domain between <domain> and </domain> tags and the problem between <problem> and </problem> tags.
